nodes.text: Policymaking is better informed by reporting both the ensemble-average (GDP per capita) and the time-average (DDP per capita) growth rates and their difference (ergodicity gap) rather than relying on GDP per capita alone
When incomes follow random multiplicative growth, the ensemble-average growth rate exceeds the time-average growth rate
The ensemble-average growth rate corresponds to the growth rate of GDP per capita and is approximately an income-weighted (plutocratic) average of individual growth rates
The time-average growth rate equals the growth rate of the geometric mean income (DDP per capita) and is an equally weighted (democratic) average of individual growth rates

The difference between ensemble-average and time-average growth rates defines a natural inequality measure, the ergodicity gap, which under multiplicative growth equals the mean logarithmic deviation (MLD)
The time-average growth rate and the ergodicity gap depend only on the initial and terminal income distributions and are independent of rank mobility, allowing estimation from cross-sectional data
Method: Model incomes with random multiplicative growth (Gibrat style) and identify ergodicity transformation by taking logarithms so growth rates become ergodic observables
Result (general): The ergodic individual growth rate is g_i = Delta ln x_i / Delta t and is ergodic while raw absolute changes are not
Result (inequality): Jensen's inequality implies g_ensemble - g_time = ln(mean x) - mean(ln x) >= 0, equal only at perfect equality; thus increase of the gap signals rising inequality
Method/Evidence: For small changes, ensemble-average growth rate approximates sum over i of w_i g_i where weights w_i are income shares, making it plutocratic
Method/Evidence: Time-average growth rate can be computed as average of individual log-growth rates or from geometric mean y(t)=exp(mean ln x(t)), yielding DDP per capita
Result: The time-average growth rate can be estimated from cross-sectional quantile data by computing changes in mean log income between periods, avoiding need for panel data
Evidence/Empirical method: Applied measures to United States and France using World Inequality Database data, computing annual ensemble and time-average growth rates and ergodicity gap (MLD)
Result (US): From 1966-1980 ensemble and time-average growth were similar, but since 1980 GDP per capita (ensemble) grew substantially faster than DDP per capita (time), increasing the ergodicity gap
Result (France): Over the same period ensemble and time-average growth rates remained much closer and the ergodicity gap was roughly stable

Conclusion: Relying only on GDP per capita can misrepresent the typical citizen experience and create political disconnect when ensemble growth outpaces time-average growth; reporting both rates and the ergodicity gap would better inform policy
Limitation: DDP per capita requires positive incomes and is sensitive to measurement of low incomes, so truncation or careful treatment of bottom quantiles may be necessary in empirical application
